<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/16/massive-hack-targets-twitters-prominent-users?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Logging Onto Twitter Like
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Donald Glover walking into fire" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=373 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/L39f1L94V0ydlWd6bt/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Donald Glover walking into fire" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/L39f1L94V0ydlWd6bt/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On a normal day, Twitter is mayhem. Throw in the <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/15/hackers-appear-to-target-twitter-accounts-of-elon-musk-bill-gates-others-in-digital-currency-scam.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">simultaneous and widespread hacking</a> of heads of state and billionaire accounts? Even the Joker would say, “Don't you think this is a little much?” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, bitcoin spammers appeared to hack the accounts of some of the most powerful people in the world—Barack Obama, Bill Gates, Jeff Bezos, Joe Biden, to name just a few—leading initially to lots of jokes but eventually to deep concern.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The message the hackers posted on these accounts was a <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/07/15/twitter-accounts-hacked-crypto-scam/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">typical crypto scam technique</a>, TechCrunch reminds us. Here’s an example: </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><img src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNzQzL3NjYW1fZnJvbV9lbG9uX211c2sucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIn0=" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Elon Musk's compromised Twitter account</em> </small></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Scammers said they’d double any bitcoin sent to an address, and the ploy was so simple it just did work. The address linked to the scam received <a href="https://www.coindesk.com/hackers-take-over-prominent-crypto-twitter-accounts-in-simultaneous-attack?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">more than $103,000</a> worth of bitcoin, CoinDesk reported. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The response</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After hours of confusion and a muted response from the Twitter comms department, CEO Jack Dorsey tweeted, “Tough day for us at Twitter. We all feel terrible this happened. We’re diagnosing and will share everything we can when we have a more complete understanding of exactly what happened.” Twitter stock fell 3% after hours.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">A small twist: </strong>All of the hacked accounts were “verified,” essentially the celebs of Twitter and owners of the coveted blue check mark on their handles. Twitter blocked those accounts from tweeting at around 3:15PT, and then allowed the blue checks to once again bestow their wisdom upon us two hours later.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>In the interim, a mini-French Revolution took place on the platform where the Twitter proletariat </span><span><a href="https://twitter.com/tobydoyhowell/status/1283529192953581571?s=20&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">assumed control</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>This is an awful, awful look for Twitter and certainly the worst security breach it’s ever suffered. Considering its central place in political, economic, and cultural discourse, the company has a huge mountain to climb to prove it can be trusted as a communication platform. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/15/football-season-serious-jeopardy?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Who’s Ready for Some Football?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Cracked Football" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNzQyL2NyYWNrZWRfZm9vdGJhbGwuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Apparently no one. Even though the pandemic struck during football’s offseason, neither the <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/notre-dame-and-everyone-else-is-feeling-bleak-about-college-football-11594814400?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">NCAA</a> nor the <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-nfl-is-supposed-to-start-soon-it-doesnt-have-a-plan-yet-11594724404?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">NFL</a> have put forward a concrete plan for the sport’s safe return. When you scan the recent statements of some major football programs, the warning signs are clear—the football season this fall is very much in doubt. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Michigan: </strong></span><span>In a press release yesterday, the Big Ten powerhouse </span><span><a href="https://sports.yahoo.com/in-announcing-ticket-policy-michigan-acknowledges-there-may-not-be-a-college-football-season-151117833.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wrote</a></span><span>, “if U-M is able to have a 2020 football season,” it would be played with a reduced capacity crowd or no fans at all. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Notre Dame:</strong></span><span> Fighting Irish athletic director Jack Swarbrick told the WSJ that if the country doesn't get a handle on the pandemic, “the only two options are no season or to explore the spring.”</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> “There’s virtually no chance of playing college football in any recognizable form this fall,” <a href="https://sports.yahoo.com/time-to-face-reality-no-one-is-playing-college-football-in-the-fall-170634809.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">writes</a> Pete Thamel of Yahoo Sports. That could be a disaster for athletic department budgets and local economies. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">On the professional side...</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The money, like the linemen, is even bigger. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>A canceled NFL season is the nightmare scenario for TV networks—NFL games accounted for </span><span><a href="https://adage.com/article/media/nfl-games-account-nearly-three-quarters-years-top-100-broadcasts/2225851?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">73 of the top 100 broadcasts</a></span><span> in 2019, AdAge reports.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Ripple effect: Losing live sports would be a J.J. Watt-sized hit to the pay-TV sector that suffered its </span><span><a href="https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/cord-cutting-explodes-q1-pay-tv-worst-losses-1234601796/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">biggest decline ever</a></span><span> in Q1 as the pandemic supercharged cord-cutting.  </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> While other U.S. sports like the NBA and MLS have mobilized, football's outsized impact on everything from TV to higher ed makes it a much higher-stakes problem to solve. Everyone has pigskin in the game.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/15/walmart-require-maskwearing-stores?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Walmart Asks for Masks
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="UNIONDALE, NEW YORK - APRIL 17:  People wearing masks and gloves wait to..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNzM5L2Nvcm9uYXZpcnVzX3BhbmRlbWljX2NhdXMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Al Bello/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, megaretailer Walmart <a href="https://apnews.com/2efc9640fe70badfa6c8f6f5b3923f68?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">brought</a> the weight of its No. 1 Fortune 500 spot to the U.S.’ mask-wearing conversation. Starting Monday, Walmart will require customers to cover their faces in all its 5,000+ stores. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory:</strong> The CDC says that to slow the spread of the coronavirus, we all need to cover our mouths and noses like we’re throwing out the spinach we forgot about in the bottom of the fridge. Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan <a href="https://www.foxbusiness.com/economy/feds-kaplan-says-wearing-masks-is-key-to-us-economic-growth?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said</a> last week that mask-wearing is the key to an economic recovery.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Patchwork state and local laws have caused confusion and spurred retailers to ask governors and the White House for a consistent national policy. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But that hasn’t panned out, so businesses are taking the lead. Walmart is the largest retailer to drop the hammer after months of ambiguity, joining Best Buy, Costco, Apple, and <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/list-of-chains-requiring-customers-wear-masks-walmart-starbucks-2020-7#sams-club-2?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">others</a>. To enforce the rule, Walmart will bring on specially trained “health ambassadors” who will be stationed by store entrances. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ Curious what this means for retail more broadly?</strong> Retail Brew’s Halie LeSavage <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2020/07/15/best-buy-starbucks-will-require-masks-stores-effective-today?email=eliza@morningbrew.com&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">can help</a>.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When we visit the wine shop, endless rows of Pinot Noir, Sauvignon Blanc, and obscure Slovakian blends laugh in our puzzled faces. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The very thought of asking the clerk what “skin contact” means sends us racing for the exit.</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/15/zoom-video-moves-hardware?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Zoom Just Got Harder
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Zoom from Home " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNzQxL3pvb21fZnJvbV9ob21lLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Zoom Video</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Zoom is an enterprise video conferencing app, a romantic spot for a first date, and now...a hardware player? Yesterday, it <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/15/zoom-expands-into-hardware-with-599-video-chat-device.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">revealed</a> a $599 “all-in-one personal collaboration device” called Zoom for Home—DTEN ME (DTEN is Zoom's hardware partner). The gadget's purpose is to create a better remote work environment by making video communications even more immersive and intuitive. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Zoom for Home will pack...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>A 27-inch screen </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Three wide-angle cameras</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Eight microphones</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>One</span><span><strong style="color:#000"> </strong></span><span>touchscreen display</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While Zoom for Home carries a hefty price tag in comparison to its competitors—Google's Nest Hub can run as low as $90—Zoom's offering screams “company card” as some knowledge workers transition to <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/12/twitter-announces-blanket-work-home-policy-signaling-shift?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">WFH forever</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Emerging Tech Brew writer Ryan Duffy is bullish on this move, arguing that “corporate money earmarked for commercial real estate can now be funneled into Zoom hardware.” But that assumes corporations will be willing (or able) to get out of those pricey office leases. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here:</strong> Do you think Zoom’s hardware move will pay off? <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/kI2wGCAE?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Share your opinion</a>. </p>

<img alt="Early Amazon home page" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNzM4L2Vhcmx5X2FtYXpvbl9ob21lX3BhZ2UucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On July 16, 1995, exactly 25 years ago today, Amazon <a href="https://qz.com/734985/this-is-what-amazons-homepage-looked-like-when-it-launched-21-years-ago-this-month/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">opened for business</a> as an online bookstore. The picture above shows the website one month later. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Now, the company is worth $1.5+ trillion, founder and CEO Jeff Bezos is the richest man in the world, and it’s sold more than 100 million talking robot devices. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Test your knowledge of Amazon by taking our <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/15/quiz-think-know-amazon?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">short quiz</a>.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FROM THE CREW
</h3>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="books" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MzMvYnJld19zX2Jvb2tzaGVsZi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Every other Thursday, we’ll bring you a few of our favorite business-related reads. This week, it’s the economy, stupid: how past recessions shape where we are now, new approaches to economic thinking, and the nagging effects of inequality. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://bookshop.org/a/9879/9780143110354?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Crashed</em></a></span><span> by Adam Tooze may be the definitive account of the 2008 financial crisis's effect on the global economic system. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://bookshop.org/a/9879/9781603587969?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Doughnut Economics</em></a></span><span> by Kate Raworth offers a 21st century approach to economic thinking that sets aside a fixation on endless growth to focus on sustainability, equality, and social justice. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><a href="https://bookshop.org/a/9879/9780674919310?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Unbound</em></a></span><span> by Heather Boushey breaks down how inequality hurts human capital, subverts political processes, and holds back economies.  </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You can find a few bonus recommendations from this installment on the <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/extras/bookshelf?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Brew’s Bookshelf homepage</a>. </p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn a normal day, Twitter is mayhem. Throw in the \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/15/hackers-appear-to-target-twitter-accounts-of-elon-musk-bill-gates-others-in-digital-currency-scam.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esimultaneous and widespread hacking\u003c/a\u003e of heads of state and billionaire accounts? Even the Joker would say, “Don't you think this is a little much?” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, bitcoin spammers appeared to hack the accounts of some of the most powerful people in the world—Barack Obama, Bill Gates, Jeff Bezos, Joe Biden, to name just a few—leading initially to lots of jokes but eventually to deep concern.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe message the hackers posted on these accounts was a \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/07/15/twitter-accounts-hacked-crypto-scam/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etypical crypto scam technique\u003c/a\u003e, TechCrunch reminds us. Here’s an example: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNzQzL3NjYW1fZnJvbV9lbG9uX211c2sucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIn0=\" class=\"img-responsive\" width=\"640\" style=\"width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;\" alt=\"\" data-reactroot=\"\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e \u003cem\u003eElon Musk's compromised Twitter account\u003c/em\u003e \u003c/small\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eScammers said they’d double any bitcoin sent to an address, and the ploy was so simple it just did work. The address linked to the scam received \u003ca href=\"https://www.coindesk.com/hackers-take-over-prominent-crypto-twitter-accounts-in-simultaneous-attack?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emore than $103,000\u003c/a\u003e worth of bitcoin, CoinDesk reported. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe response\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter hours of confusion and a muted response from the Twitter comms department, CEO Jack Dorsey tweeted, “Tough day for us at Twitter. We all feel terrible this happened. We’re diagnosing and will share everything we can when we have a more complete understanding of exactly what happened.” Twitter stock fell 3% after hours.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eA small twist: \u003c/strong\u003eAll of the hacked accounts were “verified,” essentially the celebs of Twitter and owners of the coveted blue check mark on their handles. Twitter blocked those accounts from tweeting at around 3:15PT, and then allowed the blue checks to once again bestow their wisdom upon us two hours later.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIn the interim, a mini-French Revolution took place on the platform where the Twitter proletariat \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/tobydoyhowell/status/1283529192953581571?s=20\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eassumed control\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThis is an awful, awful look for Twitter and certainly the worst security breach it’s ever suffered. Considering its central place in political, economic, and cultural discourse, the company has a huge mountain to climb to prove it can be trusted as a communication platform. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F07%2F16%2Fmassive-hack-targets-twitters-prominent-users\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNzQyL2NyYWNrZWRfZm9vdGJhbGwuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eApparently no one. Even though the pandemic struck during football’s offseason, neither the \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/notre-dame-and-everyone-else-is-feeling-bleak-about-college-football-11594814400?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eNCAA\u003c/a\u003e nor the \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-nfl-is-supposed-to-start-soon-it-doesnt-have-a-plan-yet-11594724404?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eNFL\u003c/a\u003e have put forward a concrete plan for the sport’s safe return. When you scan the recent statements of some major football programs, the warning signs are clear—the football season this fall is very much in doubt. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMichigan: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn a press release yesterday, the Big Ten powerhouse \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://sports.yahoo.com/in-announcing-ticket-policy-michigan-acknowledges-there-may-not-be-a-college-football-season-151117833.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrote\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, “if U-M is able to have a 2020 football season,” it would be played with a reduced capacity crowd or no fans at all. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eNotre Dame:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Fighting Irish athletic director Jack Swarbrick told the WSJ that if the country doesn't get a handle on the pandemic, “the only two options are no season or to explore the spring.”\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e “There’s virtually no chance of playing college football in any recognizable form this fall,” \u003ca href=\"https://sports.yahoo.com/time-to-face-reality-no-one-is-playing-college-football-in-the-fall-170634809.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrites\u003c/a\u003e Pete Thamel of Yahoo Sports. That could be a disaster for athletic department budgets and local economies. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eOn the professional side...\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe money, like the linemen, is even bigger. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eA canceled NFL season is the nightmare scenario for TV networks—NFL games accounted for \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://adage.com/article/media/nfl-games-account-nearly-three-quarters-years-top-100-broadcasts/2225851?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e73 of the top 100 broadcasts\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in 2019, AdAge reports.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eRipple effect: Losing live sports would be a J.J. Watt-sized hit to the pay-TV sector that suffered its \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/cord-cutting-explodes-q1-pay-tv-worst-losses-1234601796/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebiggest decline ever\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in Q1 as the pandemic supercharged cord-cutting.  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e While other U.S. sports like the NBA and MLS have mobilized, football's outsized impact on everything from TV to higher ed makes it a much higher-stakes problem to solve. collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, megaretailer Walmart \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/2efc9640fe70badfa6c8f6f5b3923f68?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebrought\u003c/a\u003e the weight of its No. 1 Fortune 500 spot to the U.S.’ mask-wearing conversation. Starting Monday, Walmart will require customers to cover their faces in all its 5,000+ stores. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory:\u003c/strong\u003e The CDC says that to slow the spread of the coronavirus, we all need to cover our mouths and noses like we’re throwing out the spinach we forgot about in the bottom of the fridge. Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan \u003ca href=\"https://www.foxbusiness.com/economy/feds-kaplan-says-wearing-masks-is-key-to-us-economic-growth?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid\u003c/a\u003e last week that mask-wearing is the key to an economic recovery.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePatchwork state and local laws have caused confusion and spurred retailers to ask governors and the White House for a consistent national policy. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut that hasn’t panned out, so businesses are taking the lead. Walmart is the largest retailer to drop the hammer after months of ambiguity, joining Best Buy, Costco, Apple, and \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/list-of-chains-requiring-customers-wear-masks-walmart-starbucks-2020-7#sams-club-2?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eothers\u003c/a\u003e. To enforce the rule, Walmart will bring on specially trained “health ambassadors” who will be stationed by store entrances. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ Curious what this means for retail more broadly?\u003c/strong\u003e Retail Brew’s Halie LeSavage \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2020/07/15/best-buy-starbucks-will-require-masks-stores-effective-today?email=eliza@morningbrew.com\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" The gadget's purpose is to create a better remote work environment by making video communications even more immersive and intuitive. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eZoom for Home will pack...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eA 27-inch screen \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhile Zoom for Home carries a hefty price tag in comparison to its competitors—Google's Nest Hub can run as low as $90—Zoom's offering
